title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: For a school fundraiser, Chandler needs to sell 12 rolls of wrapping paper. So far, he has sold 3 rolls to his grandmother, 4 rolls to his uncle, and 3 rolls to a neighbor. How many more rolls of wrapping paper does Chandler need to sell?

Chandler has sold a total of 3 + 4 + 3 = <<3+4+3=10>>10 rolls of wrapping paper.
He needs to sell 12 - 10 = <<12-10=2>>2 more rolls of wrapping paper. Answer: \boxed{2}.

Therefore, Chandler needs to sell 12 - 10 = <<12-10=2>>2 more rolls of wrapping paper. Answer: \boxed{2}.

Therefore, he still needs to sell 12 - 10 = <<12-10=2>>2 more rolls of wrapping paper. Answer: \boxed{2}.

text:

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Jackson’s mom packs him a peanut butter and jelly sandwich for his school lunch on Wednesdays and Fridays. There are 36 weeks of school and Jackson has only missed 1 Wednesday and 2 Fridays. How many peanut butter and jelly sandwiches did he eat for lunch this school year?

There are 36 weeks of school so there are 36 weeks * 2 days he has PB&J or 72 days of PB&J
Jackson has only missed 1 Wednesday and 2 Fridays for a total of 1 Wednesday + 2 Fridays = <<1+2=3>>3 days
He would have eaten 72 PB&J - 3 absences = <<72-3=69>>69 sandwiches this whole school year. Answer: \boxed{69}.


Question: Jackson’s mom packs him a peanut butter and jelly sandwich for his school lunch on Wednesdays and Fridays. There are 36 weeks of school and Jackson has only missed 1 Wednesday and 2 Fridays. How many peanut butter and jelly sandwiches did he eat for lunch this school year?

There are 2 days of the week that Jackson's mom packs him a sandwich: Wednesday and Friday.
He missed 1 Wednesday and 2 Fridays: 1 + 2 = <<1+2=3>>3 days missed.
He was in school for 36 weeks, so he was there for 36 * 2 = <<36*2=72>>72 days.
Thus, he ate 72 - 3 = <<72-3=69>>69 peanut butter and jelly sandwiches. Answer: \boxed{69}.


Question: Jackson’s mom packs him a peanut butter and jelly sandwich for his school lunch on Wednesdays and Fridays. There are 36 weeks of school and Jackson has only missed 1 Wednesday and 2 Fridays. How many peanut butter and jelly sandwiches did he eat for lunch this school year?

Jackson missed 1 Wednesday and 2 Fridays so that’s 2+1 = <<1+2=3>>3 days of school
There are 2 days of the week that Jackson gets a peanut butter and jelly sandwich which means he needed enough sandwiches for 2*36 = <<2*36=72>>72 school lunch days
If he missed 3 days a year then that means he got 72-3 = <<72-3=69>>69 peanut butter and jelly sandwiches. Answer: \boxed{69}.


Question: Jackson’s mom packs him a peanut butter and jelly sandwich for his school lunch on Wednesdays and Fridays. There are 36 weeks of school and Jackson has only missed 1 Wednesday and 2 Fridays. How many peanut butter and jelly sandwiches did he eat for lunch this school year?

The number of Wednesdays he ate a peanut butter and jelly sandwich is 36 - 1 = <<36-1=35>>35.
The number of Fridays he ate a peanut butter and jelly sandwich is 36 - 2 = <<36-2=34>>34.
He ate 35 + 34 = <<35+34=69>>69 peanut butter and jelly sandwiches. Answer: \boxed{69}.


Question: Jackson's oldest son gets 4 cookies after school and his youngest son gets 2 cookies after school.  If there are 54 cookies in a box, how many days will the box last?

Jackson's sons eat a total of 4 + 2 = <<4+2=6>>6 cookies a day after school.
A 54-cookie box will last 54/6 = <<54/6=9>>9 days. Answer: \boxed{9}.


Question: Jackson’s mom packs him a peanut butter and jelly sandwich for his school lunch on Wednesdays and Fridays. There are 36 weeks of school and Jackson has only missed 1 Wednesday and 2 Fridays. How many peanut butter and jelly sandwiches did he eat for lunch this school year?
text:
Jackson's mom packs him a sandwich on Wednesdays and Fridays, so he eats a total of 2 sandwiches per week.
There are 36 weeks of school in a year, so Jackson would eat 2 sandwiches/week * 36 weeks = <<2*36=72>>72 sandwiches in a school year.
However, Jackson missed 1 Wednesday and 2 Fridays, so he missed a total of 1 + 2 = <<1+2=3>>3 days.
Therefore, Jackson actually ate 72 sandwiches - 3 missed days = <<72-3=69>>69 sandwiches for lunch this school year. Answer: \boxed{69}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Punger collects baseball cards.  He buys 60 packs of baseball cards. Each pack has 7 cards inside. He wants to put these cards in special pages to protect the cards. Each page can hold 10 cards. How many pages does he need to buy?

Punger buys a total of 60 packs x 7 cards/pack = <<60*7=420>>420 cards.
He needs to buy 420 cards / 10 cards/page = <<420/10=42>>42 pages. Answer: \boxed{42}.


Question: Punger collects baseball cards.  He buys 60 packs of baseball cards. Each pack has 7 cards inside. He wants to put these cards in special pages to protect the cards. Each page can hold 10 cards. How many pages does he need to buy?

He has a total of 60 x 7 = <<60*7=420>>420 baseball cards.
So, he needs to buy 420/10 = <<420/10=42>>42 pages. Answer: \boxed{42}.


Question: Punger collects baseball cards.  He buys 60 packs of baseball cards. Each pack has 7 cards inside. He wants to put these cards in special pages to protect the cards. Each page can hold 10 cards. How many pages does he need to buy?

Punger has a total of 60 packs * 7 cards/pack = <<60*7=420>>420 baseball cards.
He would need 420 cards / 10 cards/page = <<420/10=42>>42 pages. Answer: \boxed{42}.


Question: Punger collects baseball cards.  He buys 60 packs of baseball cards. Each pack has 7 cards inside. He wants to put these cards in special pages to protect the cards. Each page can hold 10 cards. How many pages does he need to buy?

Punger has a total of 60 packs x 7 cards per pack = <<60*7=420>>420 baseball cards.
Thus, he needs to buy 420 / 10 = <<420/10=42>>42 pages to store all his cards. Answer: \boxed{42}.


Question: Punger collects baseball cards.  He buys 60 packs of baseball cards. Each pack has 7 cards inside. He wants to put these cards in special pages to protect the cards. Each page can hold 10 cards. How many pages does he need to buy?

Punger bought a total of 60 packs * 7 cards per pack = <<60*7=420>>420 cards.
He will need 420 cards / 10 cards per page = <<420/10=42>>42 pages. Answer: \boxed{42}.


Question: Punger collects baseball cards.  He buys 60 packs of baseball cards. Each pack has 7 cards inside. He wants to put these cards in special pages to protect the cards. Each page can hold 10 cards. How many pages does he need to buy?
text:
Punger has a total of 60 packs x 7 cards/pack = <<60*7=420>>420 baseball cards.
To store these cards, he needs to buy 420 cards / 10 cards/page = <<420/10=42>>42 pages. Answer: \boxed{42}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: On Friday, Remy paid Sally’s Woodworking LLC a total of $20,700 for 150 pieces of furniture. Later that evening, the company’s accountant discovered that a new intern in the sales department had overcharged Remy. If the cost of a piece of furniture is $134, how much money will Sally’s Woodworking LLC reimburse Remy?

The cost of 150 pieces of furniture is 150*$134=$<<150*134=20100>>20100
The company will reimburse Remy $20100-$20700=$<<20100-20700=-600>>600. Answer: \boxed{600}.


Question: On Friday, Remy paid Sally’s Woodworking LLC a total of $20,700 for 150 pieces of furniture. Later that evening, the company’s accountant discovered that a new intern in the sales department had overcharged Remy. If the cost of a piece of furniture is $134, how much money will Sally’s Woodworking LLC reimburse Remy?

The total cost of the furniture should have been 150 * $134 = $<<150*134=20100>>20,100.
Sally’s Woodworking LLC will reimburse Remy for $20700 - $20100 = $<<20700-20100=600>>600. Answer: \boxed{600}.


Question: On Friday, Remy paid Sally’s Woodworking LLC a total of $20,700 for 150 pieces of furniture. Later that evening, the company’s accountant discovered that a new intern in the sales department had overcharged Remy. If the cost of a piece of furniture is $134, how much money will Sally’s Woodworking LLC reimburse Remy?

The cost of 150 pieces of furniture at $134 per piece is $<<150*134=20100>>20100.
The company overcharged Remy by $20100 - $20700 = $<<20100-20700=600>>600. Answer: \boxed{600}.


Question: On Friday, Remy paid Sally’s Woodworking LLC a total of $20,700 for 150 pieces of furniture. Later that evening, the company’s accountant discovered that a new intern in the sales department had overcharged Remy. If the cost of a piece of furniture is $134, how much money will Sally’s Woodworking LLC reimburse Remy?

The total amount that Remy paid for the furniture is $20,700.
The total number of furniture pieces bought is 150.
So the cost per furniture piece is $20700/150 = $<<20700/150=138>>138.
Hence, Sally's Woodworking LLC will reimburse Remy with $138-$134 = $<<138-134=4>>4.
Therefore, Sally's Woodworking LLC will reimburse Remy with a total of $4*150 = $<<4*150=600>>600. Answer: \boxed{600}.


Question: On Friday, Remy paid Sally’s Woodworking LLC a total of $20,700 for 150 pieces of furniture. Later that evening, the company’s accountant discovered that a new intern in the sales department had overcharged Remy. If the cost of a piece of furniture is $134, how much money will Sally’s Woodworking LLC reimburse Remy?

The total amount Remy should have paid is 150 * $134 = $<<150*134=20100>>20,100.
Thus, Sally's Woodworking LLC will reimburse Remy $20,100 - $20,700 = $<<20100-20700=600>>600. Answer: \boxed{600}.


Question: On Friday, Remy paid Sally’s Woodworking LLC a total of $20,700 for 150 pieces of furniture. Later that evening, the company’s accountant discovered that a new intern in the sales department had overcharged Remy. If the cost of a piece of furniture is $134, how much money will Sally’s Woodworking LLC reimburse Remy?
text:
The total cost of the furniture is $20,700.
The correct total cost should have been $134 * 150 = $20,100.
Therefore, Sally's Woodworking LLC will reimburse Remy with $20,700 - $20,100 = $600. Answer: \boxed{600}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Seth bought some boxes of oranges. He gave a box to his mother. He then gave away half of the remaining boxes. If Seth has 4 boxes of oranges left, how many boxes did he buy in the first place?

Let X be the number of boxes of oranges Seth bought.
Seth gave 1 box to his mother so he kept X-1 boxes.
He gave away half of the remaining boxes, so he kept (X-1)/2 boxes.
He has 4 boxes left, so (X-1)/2 = 4
Multiplying through the parentheses we get X - 1 = 4 * 2 = <<4*2=8>>8.
Adding 1 to both sides we get X = 8 + 1 = <<8+1=9>>9
Seth bought 9 boxes of oranges. Answer: \boxed{9}.


Question: Seth bought some boxes of oranges. He gave a box to his mother. He then gave away half of the remaining boxes. If Seth has 4 boxes of oranges left, how many boxes did he buy in the first place?

Let x be the number of boxes he bought.
After giving a box to his mother, Seth had x-1 boxes left.
He gave away half, so he had (x-1)/2 left.
Since he has 4 boxes left, (x-1)/2 = 4.
Multiplying both sides of the equation by 2 gives x-1 = 8.
Adding 1 to both sides of the equation gives x = 9. Answer: \boxed{9}.


Question: Seth bought some boxes of oranges. He gave a box to his mother. He then gave away half of the remaining boxes. If Seth has 4 boxes of oranges left, how many boxes did he buy in the first place?

Let's start solving step by step
Let 'x' be the number of boxes Seth bought
After giving a box to his mother, he has 'x-1' boxes remaining
Then he gave away half or (x-1)/2
And after giving away half of the boxes he has 4 left
Therefore (x-1)/2=4
Multiplying throughout the equation by 2 we have: x-1=8
Adding 1 to both sides we have: x=9
So Seth bought 9 boxes of oranges. Answer: \boxed{9}.


Question: Jillian had 80 oranges which she had bought to give to her friends. She divided each orange into ten equal pieces for each friend to get four pieces. How many friends were there?

Jillian has a total of 80 * 10 = <<80*10=800>>800 equal pieces of oranges.
Thus she had 800 / 4 = <<800/4=200>>200 friends. Answer: \boxed{200}.


Question: Jillian had 80 oranges which she had bought to give to her friends. She divided each orange into ten equal pieces for each friend to get four pieces. How many friends were there?

Jillian had a total of 80 x 10 = <<80*10=800>>800 pieces.
Therefore there were 800 / 4 = <<800/4=200>>200 friends. Answer: \boxed{200}.


Question: Seth bought some boxes of oranges. He gave a box to his mother. He then gave away half of the remaining boxes. If Seth has 4 boxes of oranges left, how many boxes did he buy in the first place?
text:
Let X be the number of boxes of oranges Seth bought.
After giving a box to his mother, Seth had X-1 boxes remaining.
He gave away half of the remaining boxes, so he kept (X-1)/2 boxes.
He has 4 boxes left, so (X-1)/2 = 4.
Multiplying through the parentheses we get X - 1 = 4 * 2 = 8.
Adding 1 to both sides we get X = 8 + 1 = 9.
Seth bought 9 boxes of oranges. Answer: \boxed{9}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Marla has a grid of squares that has 10 rows and 15 squares in each row. She colors 4 rows of 6 squares in the middle of the grid with red. She colors all squares on the first 2 and last 2 rows with blue. Then she colors the rest with green. How many squares does Marla color green?

In total, there are 10 x 15 = <<10*15=150>>150 squares.
Marla colors 4 x 6 = <<4*6=24>>24 squares in red.
She colors 2 x 15 + 2 x 15 = 60 squares in blue.
So, the total is 24 + 60 = <<24+60=84>>84 squares.
Thus, Marla colors 150 - 84 = <<150-84=66>>66 squares in green. Answer: \boxed{66}.


Question: Marla has a grid of squares that has 10 rows and 15 squares in each row. She colors 4 rows of 6 squares in the middle of the grid with red. She colors all squares on the first 2 and last 2 rows with blue. Then she colors the rest with green. How many squares does Marla color green?

There are 10 x 15 = <<10*15=150>>150 squares in the grid.
There are 4 x 6 = <<4*6=24>>24 squares colored red.
There are 2 + 2 = <<2+2=4>>4 rows colored blue.
So, there are 4 x 15 = <<4*15=60>>60 squares colored blue.
Hence, a total of 24 + 60 = <<24+60=84>>84 squares were colored either red or blue.
Therefore, 150 - 84 = <<150-84=66>>66 squares were colored green by Marla. Answer: \boxed{66}.


Question: Marla has a grid of squares that has 10 rows and 15 squares in each row. She colors 4 rows of 6 squares in the middle of the grid with red. She colors all squares on the first 2 and last 2 rows with blue. Then she colors the rest with green. How many squares does Marla color green?

There are 10 x 15 = <<10*15=150>>150 squares on the grid.
Marla colored 4 x 6 = <<4*6=24>>24 squares red.
She colored 2 + 2 = <<2+2=4>>4 rows blue.
So, there are a total of 4 x 15 = <<4*15=60>>60 squares that are blue.
Thus, there are a total of 24 + 60 = <<24+60=84>>84 squares that Marla colored red and blue.
Hence, Marla colored 150 - 84 = <<150-84=66>>66 squares green. Answer: \boxed{66}.


Question: Nadine collected different colored pebbles. She has 20 white pebbles and half as many red pebbles. How many pebbles does she have in all?

Nadine has 20/2 = <<20/2=10>>10 red pebbles.
So, Nadine has 20 white + 10 red = <<20+10=30>>30 pebbles in all. Answer: \boxed{30}.


Question: Nadine collected different colored pebbles. She has 20 white pebbles and half as many red pebbles. How many pebbles does she have in all?

Nadine has 20/2 = <<20/2=10>>10 red pebbles.
Therefore, Nadine has 20 + 10 = <<20+10=30>>30 pebbles in all. Answer: \boxed{30}.


Question: Marla has a grid of squares that has 10 rows and 15 squares in each row. She colors 4 rows of 6 squares in the middle of the grid with red. She colors all squares on the first 2 and last 2 rows with blue. Then she colors the rest with green. How many squares does Marla color green?
text:
The total number of squares on the grid is 10 x 15 = <<10*15=150>>150 squares.
Marla colors 4 x 6 = <<4*6=24>>24 squares in red.
She also colors 2 + 2 = <<2+2=4>>4 rows of squares in blue, which is a total of 4 x 15 = <<4*15=60>>60 squares.
Therefore, the total number of squares colored either red or blue is 24 + 60 = <<24+60=84>>84 squares.
Thus, the number of squares colored green by Marla is 150 - 84 = <<150-84=66>>66 squares. Answer: \boxed{66}.

title:

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Catriona has 8 goldfish in her aquarium. She has 4 more angelfish than goldfish. Also, she has twice as many guppies as angelfish. How many fish does Catriona have in her aquarium?

Catriona has 8 + 4 = <<8+4=12>>12 angelfish.
Also, she has 12 x 2 = <<12*2=24>>24 guppies.
Therefore, Catriona has a total of 8 + 12 + 24 = <<8+12+24=44>>44 fish in her aquarium. Answer: \boxed{44}.


Question: Catriona has 8 goldfish in her aquarium. She has 4 more angelfish than goldfish. Also, she has twice as many guppies as angelfish. How many fish does Catriona have in her aquarium?

If Catriona has 8 goldfish in her aquarium, she has 8+4 = <<8+4=12>>12 angelfish.
She has 2*12 = <<2*12=24>>24 guppies.
Altogether, Catriona has 8+12+24 = <<8+12+24=44>>44 fish. Answer: \boxed{44}.

Therefore, Catriona has a total of 8 + 12 + 24 = <<8+12+24=44>>44 fish in her aquarium. Answer: \boxed{44}.

Therefore, Catriona has 8 + 12 + 24 = <<8+12+24=44>>44 fish in her aquarium. Answer: \boxed{44}.

Catriona has 8 + 4 = <<8+4=12>>12 angelfish.
So, she has 12 x 2 = <<12*2=24>>24 guppies.
Therefore, Catriona has a total of 8 + 12 + 24 = <<8+12+24=44>>44 fish in her aquarium. Answer: \boxed{44}.


Question: Catriona has 8 goldfish in her aquarium. She has 4 more angelfish than goldfish. Also, she has twice as many guppies as angelfish. How many fish does Catriona have in her aquarium?
text:
If Catriona has 8 goldfish in her aquarium, she has 8+4 = <<8+4=12>>12 angelfish.
She has 2*12 = <<2*12=24>>24 guppies.
Altogether, Catriona has 8+12+24 = <<8+12+24=44>>44 fish. Answer: \boxed{44}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Carl has a jar full of marbles. He takes out 12 marbles to play a game with, but he accidentally drops them and 1/2 the marbles get lost. So Carl takes out 10 more marbles. While he is playing his game his mother comes home with another bag of marbles for him, which has 25 marbles in it. If Carl can't find his lost marbles, then how many marbles is he going to put in the jar after he plays his game, from both his original marbles and the new ones?

Before Carl lost the marbles from dropping them, he had 12 marbles in the jar.
If 1/2 the marbles get lost, this means 1/2*12 = <<1/2*12=6>>6 marbles get lost.
This means after losing the marbles, Carl has 12-6 = <<12-6=6>>6 marbles left in the jar.
After taking out 10 more marbles, Carl has 6+10 = <<6+10=16>>16 marbles in the jar.
When his mother comes home with the new bag, the total number of marbles in the jar will be 16+25 = <<16+25=41>>41 marbles. Answer: \boxed{41}.


Question: Carl has a jar full of marbles. He takes out 12 marbles to play a game with, but he accidentally drops them and 1/2 the marbles get lost. So Carl takes out 10 more marbles. While he is playing his game his mother comes home with another bag of marbles for him, which has 25 marbles in it. If Carl can't find his lost marbles, then how many marbles is he going to put in the jar after he plays his game, from both his original marbles and the new ones?

Carl had 12 marbles and dropped half, leaving 12/2 = <<12/2=6>>6 marbles lost.
So Carl has 12 - 6 = <<12-6=6>>6 marbles left.
Carl then takes out 10 more marbles so he now has 6 + 10 = <<6+10=16>>16 marbles.
Then his mother gives him another 25 marbles, so he now has 16 + 25 = <<16+25=41>>41 marbles. Answer: \boxed{41}.


Question: Carl has a jar full of marbles. He takes out 12 marbles to play a game with, but he accidentally drops them and 1/2 the marbles get lost. So Carl takes out 10 more marbles. While he is playing his game his mother comes home with another bag of marbles for him, which has 25 marbles in it. If Carl can't find his lost marbles, then how many marbles is he going to put in the jar after he plays his game, from both his original marbles and the new ones?

Before Carl played his game he took out 12 marbles and then lost 1/2 of them so he lost 12/2 = <<12/2=6>>6 marbles
Carl then took out 10 more marbles so he had 12-6+10 = <<12-6+10=16>>16 marbles
His mother brought him 25 more marbles so after he plays his game he will have 16+25 = <<16+25=41>>41 marbles. Answer: \boxed{41}.


Question: Carl has a jar full of marbles. He takes out 12 marbles to play a game with, but he accidentally drops them and 1/2 the marbles get lost. So Carl takes out 10 more marbles. While he is playing his game his mother comes home with another bag of marbles for him, which has 25 marbles in it. If Carl can't find his lost marbles, then how many marbles is he going to put in the jar after he plays his game, from both his original marbles and the new ones?

Carl initially had 12 marbles, but after dropping them, 1/2 * 12 = <<12*1/2=6>>6 marbles are lost.
So Carl now has 12 - 6 = <<12-6=6>>6 marbles remaining.
After taking out 10 more marbles Carl has a total of 6 + 10 = <<6+10=16>>16 marbles.
When his mother arrives, Carl will have 16 + 25 = <<16+25=41>>41 marbles in total. Answer: \boxed{41}.


Question: Two boys, Ben and Leo,  are fond of playing marbles. Ben has 56 marbles, while Leo has 20 more marbles than Ben. They put the marbles in one jar. How many marbles in the jar?

Leo has 56 + 20 = <<56+20=76>>76 marbles.
Therefore, the jar has 56 + 76 = <<56+76=132>>132 marbles. Answer: \boxed{132}.


Question: Carl has a jar full of marbles. He takes out 12 marbles to play a game with, but he accidentally drops them and 1/2 the marbles get lost. So Carl takes out 10 more marbles. While he is playing his game his mother comes home with another bag of marbles for him, which has 25 marbles in it. If Carl can't find his lost marbles, then how many marbles is he going to put in the jar after he plays his game, from both his original marbles and the new ones?
text:
Before Carl plays his game, he has 12 marbles in the jar.
If he loses 1/2 of the marbles, he loses 1/2 * 12 = 6 marbles.
So he is left with 12 - 6 = 6 marbles.
After taking out 10 more marbles, he has 6 + 10 = 16 marbles in total.
When his mother brings him the new bag of marbles, he will have 16 + 25 = 41 marbles in total. Answer: \boxed{41}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Rene can finish reading 30 pages in 60 minutes. Lulu can read 27 pages in 60 minutes and Cherry can read 25 pages in 60 minutes. If they have been reading for 240 minutes now, how many pages have they finished reading in total?

Rene can read 30 x (240/60) = <<30*(240/60)=120>>120 pages in 240 minutes.
Lulu can read 27 x (240/60) = <<27*(240/60)=108>>108 pages in 240 minutes.
And, Cherry can read 25 x (240/60) = <<25*(240/60)=100>>100 pages in 240 minutes.
Therefore, they have altogether read 120 + 108 + 100 = <<120+108+100=328>>328 pages in 240 minutes. Answer: \boxed{328}.


Question: Rene can finish reading 30 pages in 60 minutes. Lulu can read 27 pages in 60 minutes and Cherry can read 25 pages in 60 minutes. If they have been reading for 240 minutes now, how many pages have they finished reading in total?

Rene can read 30 x 4 = <<30*4=120>>120 pages after reading for 240 minutes.
Lulu can read 27 x 4 = <<27*4=108>>108 pages after reading for 240 minutes.
Cherry can read 25 x 4 = <<25*4=100>>100 pages after reading for 240 minutes.
Therefore, they have finished reading a total of 120 + 108 + 100 = <<120+108+100=328>>328 pages. Answer: \boxed{328}.


Question: Rene can finish reading 30 pages in 60 minutes. Lulu can read 27 pages in 60 minutes and Cherry can read 25 pages in 60 minutes. If they have been reading for 240 minutes now, how many pages have they finished reading in total?

Rene can read 30 x 4 = <<30*4=120>>120 pages in 240 minutes.
Lulu can read 27 x 4 = <<27*4=108>>108 pages in 240 minutes.
Cherry can read 25 x 4 = <<25*4=100>>100 pages in 240 minutes.
Therefore, they have finished reading a total of 120 + 108 + 100 = <<120+108+100=328>>328 pages. Answer: \boxed{328}.

Question: Rene can finish reading 30 pages in 60 minutes. Lulu can read 27 pages in 60 minutes and Cherry can read 25 pages in 60 minutes. If they have been reading for 240 minutes now, how many pages have they finished reading in total?
text:
Rene can read 30 x (240/60) = <<30*(240/60)=120>>120 pages in 240 minutes.
Lulu can read 27 x (240/60) = <<27*(240/60)=108>>108 pages in 240 minutes.
Cherry can read 25 x (240/60) = <<25*(240/60)=100>>100 pages in 240 minutes.
Therefore, they have altogether read 120 + 108 + 100 = <<120+108+100=328>>328 pages in 240 minutes. Answer: \boxed{328}.
